div.p: TCHARACTERNAME, an element in the WRITING section of entries, conceptually part of the TEXTUALFEATURES component, allows us to tag the names of significant characters. It should contain only the character's name. It has no mandatory sub-elements, although you may want to use this in conjunction with the TCHARACTERIZATION element and perhaps with the TCHARACTERTTYPE/ROLE element. One optional attribute, REG, allows you to regularize the name of the character when the name is not otherwise clear in your text (e.g. adding either a first or last name to the other). The REG attribute here works the same way as the REG attribute for NAME.

Not to be confused with NAME, meaning that of someone real, not fictional. In some cases of historical fiction, both tags might be called for. Do not tag the Marys and Johns in every novel; if you have a first name and last name, still don’t tag without considering first, Is it worthwhile? (Sometimes it is: fun to watch the gradual proliferation of fictional Emmas before Austen’s.) Use this tag whenever an identifiable character name merits recording. However, you should only apply it to characters created by the writer named in your document. If the author knowingly refers to a character in another writer's work, use the TINTERTEXTUALITY element. Include the title of the originary text where possible and meaningful. For example, Christian Isobel Johnstone appropriates the name of Margaret Dods from a Walter Scott novel for one of her own characters, but if she merely based a character on his Dods you would tag “Margaret Dods” with TINTERTEXTUALITY and not TCHARACTERNAME.
